intro: Oryza sativa var. garhwalica, commonly known as the Garhwal rice, is a variant of the Asian rice species native to the Himalayan region of India. It is characterized by its short, compact grains and high yield potential, making it well-suited for the local climate and soil conditions. The plant typically grows to a height of 100–120 cm and has a robust root system that helps it thrive in mountainous terrains. It requires a warm, humid climate with ample rainfall during the growing season. This variety is also valued for its resilience to pests and diseases, contributing to its importance in the agricultural practices of the region.
